articles.headline: The Democratic Debate Lineups Are Set. Here’s What to Expect.
articles.snippet: The first night will be Elizabeth Warren’s to lose, while the second will be a four-way showdown between the rest of the top-tier candidates.
articles.abstract: The first night will be Elizabeth Warren’s to lose, while the second will be a four-way showdown between the rest of the top-tier candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two nights, four hours, so, so many candidates: the first Democratic presidential debates will be like nothing we’ve ever seen. A former vice president on stage with a self-help author. Three female candidates on one night, three female candidates the next — more than have ever been on the debate stage at once. A 37-year-old squaring off against two septuagenarians.
articles.byline: By Matt Stevens, Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Bribes and Backdoor Deals Help Foreign Firms Sell to China’s Hospitals
articles.snippet: G.E., Siemens and others have prospered in a country where corruption pervades the market for medical equipment, according to a New York Times investigation. China’s 1.4 billion people pay the price.
articles.abstract: G.E., Siemens and others have prospered in a country where corruption pervades the market for medical equipment, according to a New York Times investigation. China’s 1.4 billion people pay the price.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A trip to the sauna. A golf club membership. Luxury watches. Neatly packed bricks of red Chinese bills worth $220,000.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: Groundwork Is Laid for Opioids Settlement That Would Touch Every Corner of U.S.
articles.snippet: Each locality in the country, from small towns to major cities, would receive a payout in a settlement with the companies who made, distributed and sold opioids.
articles.abstract: Each locality in the country, from small towns to major cities, would receive a payout in a settlement with the companies who made, distributed and sold opioids.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every city, town and county in the United States could receive a payout in a settlement with the largest makers, distributors and retailers of prescription opioids, if a judge approves an innovative proposal made Friday in an Ohio federal court by lawyers for hundreds of local governments.
articles.byline: By Jan Hoffman

articles.headline: As Trump Accuses Iran, He Has One Problem: His Own Credibility
articles.snippet: For any president, accusing another country of an act of war presents a challenge to overcome skepticism at home and abroad. For a president known for falsehoods and bombast, it is far more daunting.
articles.abstract: For any president, accusing another country of an act of war presents a challenge to overcome skepticism at home and abroad. For a president known for falsehoods and bombast, it is far more daunting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To President Trump, the question of culpability in the explosions that crippled two oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman is no question at all. “It’s probably got essentially Iran written all over it,” he declared on Friday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker

articles.headline: U.S. Escalates Online Attacks on Russia’s Power Grid
articles.snippet: The Trump administration is using new authority to take more aggressive digital action in a warning to Moscow and in a demonstration of its abilities.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration is using new authority to take more aggressive digital action in a warning to Moscow and in a demonstration of its abilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is stepping up digital incursions into Russia’s electric power grid in a warning to President Vladimir V. Putin and a demonstration of how the Trump administration is using new authorities to deploy cybertools more aggressively, current and former government officials said.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: As Passions Flare in Abortion Debate, Many Americans Say ‘It’s Complicated’
articles.snippet: Abortion is anything but a simple issue. But the nuance in how most Americans think about it has all but disappeared from the political conversation, some voters say.
articles.abstract: Abortion is anything but a simple issue. But the nuance in how most Americans think about it has all but disappeared from the political conversation, some voters say.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Abortion is an issue that Lynndora Smith-Holmes goes back and forth on. “Six of one, half dozen of the other,” she said the other day as she finished her lunch break.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: How Hong Kong’s Leader Made the Biggest Political Retreat by China Under Xi
articles.snippet: Limited consultation within the Hong Kong government, and none with the public, led to an unexpected setback for local authorities and China’s government.
articles.abstract: Limited consultation within the Hong Kong government, and none with the public, led to an unexpected setback for local authorities and China’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, has a very loyal majority in the territory’s legislature. She has the complete backing of the Chinese government. She has a huge bureaucracy ready to push her agenda.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: In Face-Off With Iran, Escalation May Depend on Who Prevails Inside Washington and Tehran
articles.snippet: The attacks in the Gulf of Oman emboldens the hard-liners in Iran and the U.S., each able to argue their longtime adversary is itching for war.
articles.abstract: The attacks in the Gulf of Oman emboldens the hard-liners in Iran and the U.S., each able to argue their longtime adversary is itching for war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Iran and the United States face off in the Gulf of Oman, the risk may not be just at sea, but in Tehran and Washington, where both Iranian and American hard-liners are seizing on the moment for political advantage.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: ‘Catastrophic,’ ‘Cataclysmic’: Trump’s Tariff Threat Has Retailers Sounding Alarm
articles.snippet: Struggling to compete against online rivals, retailers could be forced to close more stores if tariffs hit Chinese footwear, toys and apparel, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Struggling to compete against online rivals, retailers could be forced to close more stores if tariffs hit Chinese footwear, toys and apparel, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Already battered by the e-commerce revolution, traditional retail stores are bracing for another blow — new tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese imports that the Trump administration is threatening to impose.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Hong Kong’s Retreat Chips Away at Xi Jinping’s Iron Image
articles.snippet: The suspension of legislation to extradite suspects to China was the biggest political reversal of Xi Jinping’s years in power. Will it undermine his rule?
articles.abstract: The suspension of legislation to extradite suspects to China was the biggest political reversal of Xi Jinping’s years in power. Will it undermine his rule?
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, was in Tajikistan on Saturday, celebrating his 66th birthday with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, when the political crisis in Hong Kong took a dramatic turn with an unexpected retreat in the face of mass protests.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Hong Kong Protesters Return to the Streets, Rejecting Leader’s Apology
articles.snippet: Protesters dismissed the apology by Carrie Lam as insincere and called for her resignation among a growing list of demands.
articles.abstract: Protesters dismissed the apology by Carrie Lam as insincere and called for her resignation among a growing list of demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Protesters poured into the streets of Hong Kong on Sunday with renewed determination and a lengthening list of demands, rejecting the government’s retreat on a contentious extradition bill and extending the political crisis gripping the semiautonomous territory.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Daniel Victor

articles.headline: Food-Delivery Couriers Exploit Desperate Migrants in France
articles.snippet: Some contractors are dealing with rate cuts by leasing their accounts to immigrants, many of them underage or in the country illegally, and taking part of their pay.
articles.abstract: Some contractors are dealing with rate cuts by leasing their accounts to immigrants, many of them underage or in the country illegally, and taking part of their pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Aymen Arfaoui strapped on a plastic Uber Eats bag and checked his cellphone for the fastest bicycle route before pedaling into the stream of cars circling the Place de la République. Time was money, and Mr. Arfaoui, a nervous 18-year-old migrant, needed cash.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Trump Wants to Neutralize Democrats on Health Care. Republicans Say Let It Go.
articles.snippet: If the president follows through on issuing a plan, it could help shape a presidential race that Democrats would like to focus largely on health care.
articles.abstract: If the president follows through on issuing a plan, it could help shape a presidential race that Democrats would like to focus largely on health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump prepares to kick off his bid for a second term this week, he is anxiously searching for a way to counter Democrats on health care, one of their central issues, even though many of his wary Republican allies would prefer he let it go for now.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Michael Tackett and Linda Qiu

articles.headline: The Youngest Child Separated From His Family at the Border Was 4 Months Old
articles.snippet: Baby Constantin spent five months of his first year in a foster home. His family got a painful look at America’s experiment with family separation as an immigration policy.
articles.abstract: Baby Constantin spent five months of his first year in a foster home. His family got a painful look at America’s experiment with family separation as an immigration policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — The text messages were coming in all day and night with only two data points: Gender and age. With each one that arrived, the on-call caseworker at Bethany Christian Services in Michigan had 15 minutes to find a foster home for another child who was en route from the border. On a brisk winter day in February 2018, Alma Acevedo got a message that caught her breath: “4 months. Boy.”
articles.byline: By Caitlin Dickerson and Todd Heisler

articles.headline: Mario Draghi Saved the Euro. Will His Successor Be Equally Committed?
articles.snippet: The exiting president of the E.C.B. famously vowed to do “whatever it takes” to preserve the eurozone currency. It is unclear whether whoever follows him can be counted on to do the same.
articles.abstract: The exiting president of the E.C.B. famously vowed to do “whatever it takes” to preserve the eurozone currency. It is unclear whether whoever follows him can be counted on to do the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINTRA, Portugal — Officially, the central bankers, economists and journalists converging on a golf resort outside Lisbon this week will be reflecting on the grand monetary experiment known as the euro, which turned 20 this year.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: What Makes a Leader?
articles.snippet: Gentle, harsh, remote, accessible. What’s a woman to be? Maybe all those things at once.
articles.abstract: Gentle, harsh, remote, accessible. What’s a woman to be? Maybe all those things at once.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You’re too accessible.”
articles.byline: By Jessica Bennett

articles.headline: Trump Adds Troops After Iran Says It Will Breach Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: As President Trump ordered the deployment of 1,000 more troops to the Middle East, Tehran was trying to get European nations to blunt American economic sanctions.
articles.abstract: As President Trump ordered the deployment of 1,000 more troops to the Middle East, Tehran was trying to get European nations to blunt American economic sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tensions between the United States and Iran flared on Monday as Tehran said it would soon breach a key element of the 2015 international pact limiting its nuclear program, while President Trump ordered another 1,000 troops to the Middle East and vowed again that Iran would not be allowed to develop a nuclear weapon.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Helene Cooper and Megan Specia

articles.headline: Why Sotheby’s Agreed to Be Bought by a Telecom Executive for $3.7 Billion
articles.snippet: Patrick Drahi’s acquisition of the auction house, which has recently struggled to turn a profit, will return it to private ownership after 31 years of being publicly traded.
articles.abstract: Patrick Drahi’s acquisition of the auction house, which has recently struggled to turn a profit, will return it to private ownership after 31 years of being publicly traded.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In recent years, the competition between the world’s two largest auction houses, Sotheby’s and Christie’s, has seemed at times like a bit of an unfair fight.
articles.byline: By Scott Reyburn, Michael J. de la Merced and Robin Pogrebin

articles.headline: The Trade War With China Has an Upside for Consumers, Too
articles.snippet: The Trump administration’s tariffs made that washing machine cost more, but gas is cheaper because the markets are jittery about the trade war.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration’s tariffs made that washing machine cost more, but gas is cheaper because the markets are jittery about the trade war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the start of the Trump administration’s trade war last year, economists and executives have repeatedly warned that consumers will ultimately end up footing the bill for tariffs through higher prices.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips

articles.headline: These Influencers Aren’t Flesh and Blood, Yet Millions Follow Them
articles.snippet: From Calvin Klein to KFC, the rise of the computer-generated influencer on social media.
articles.abstract: From Calvin Klein to KFC, the rise of the computer-generated influencer on social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: The kiss between Bella Hadid and Miquela Sousa, part of a Calvin Klein commercial last month, struck many viewers as unrealistic, even offensive.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu
